findings.title: UOD - Unnecessary Override Declaration
findings.description: The contract is implementing an override of the decimals function which simply returns the value 18, but this override is redundant since the extending token contract already specifies 18 decimals as its standard.

findings.title: RC - Redundant Calculation
findings.description: The contract sets the variable `token2Swap` equal to `_marketingPending`, making the subsequent calculation of marketingPortion using `coinsReceived * _marketingPending / token2Swap` redundant, as `token2Swap` is always equal to `_marketingPending`. This redundancy not only adds unnecessary complexity to the contract but also potentially wastes gas.

findings.title: RCS - Redundant Code Segments
findings.description: The contract includes redundant code segments such as an `if` statement with a `false` keyword and unnecessary additions of zero to variables.

findings.title: RSD - Redundant Swap Duplication
findings.description: The contract contains multiple swap methods that individually perform token swaps and transfer promotional amounts to specific addresses and features, introducing unnecessary complexity and increasing gas consumption.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract's swap functionality can lead to significant price volatility due to the potential for a huge amount of tokens being swapped for ETH, considering the highly volatile token price.

findings.title: DDP - Decimal Division Precision
findings.description: Division of decimal (fixed point) numbers can result in rounding errors due to the way that division is implemented in Solidity, leading to issues with precise calculations with decimal numbers.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: MEM - Misleading Error Messages
findings.description: The contract is using misleading error messages. These error messages do not accurately reflect the problem, making it difficult to identify and fix the issue.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions 0.8.0 and above have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide provides guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code. Adhering to a style guide can help improve the readability and maintainability of the Solidity code, making it easier for others to understand and work with.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Local scope variable shadowing occurs when a local variable with the same name as a variable in an outer scope is declared within a function or code block.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured with user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L18 - Multiple Pragma Directives
findings.description: If the contract includes multiple conflicting pragma directives, it may produce unexpected errors.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
